name: Medical Ethics
long_desc: This course provides a detailed introduction to core ethical issues in medical ethics and public policy. Topics include the moral responsibilities of health care providers to patients and various third parties such as the government or insurance companies, the status of health as a social good, questions of justice in access to health care, and questions of individual liberty and social responsibility at the ends of life including issues such as cloning, abortion, physician assistance in dying, and the definition of death. We will also examine specific ethical issues in the conduct of medical research and look at the impact of technological innovation on our notions of health, disease, life, death, and the family. While the course engages such substantive ethical issues it also attempts tosharpen students skills in practical reasoning through argument analysis, analogical reasoning, and the application of theory and principles to practical cases.

custom_fields.goals: Students will understand the most compelling arguments that have been articulated on a variety of important ethical issues in health care and they will develop the ability to 1 identify and reconstruct arguments from complex texts, 2 critically analyze moral arguments, 3 construct moral arguments.Specifically, student will learn toAnalyze the role of various social systems in shaping individual and public health.Evaluate when various kinds of inequality are or are not morally problematic.Consider how policy proposals are likely to impact inequalities.Identify constituent components of multifaceted and illdefined problems in health and health care.Draw on relevant ethical perspectives and social science evidence to propose approaches to address the problems identified.Use relevant theories of fairness and justice to evaluate the strengths and weaknesses of various proposals to produce more just or fair health systems.Draw on insights from ethics, political philosophy and medicine to produce an integrated formulation of ethical issues in health care, to formulate responses to those problems, and to evaluate the relative strengths and weaknesses of such proposals.
custom_fields.key_topics: Topics include: the moral responsibilities of health care providers to patients and various third parties such as the government or insurance companies, the status of health as a social good, questions of justice in access to health care, and questions of individual liberty and social responsibility at the ends of life including issues such as cloning, abortion, physician assisted suicide, and the definition of death.
custom_fields.assessment_structure: Attendance and class participation and short essays.
custom_fields.relevance:
DC: Equity and Justice
This course is relevant to anyone interested in health care, health policy, health-related research, ethics, social policy, law or advocacy.
custom_fields.learning_resources: Steinbock, London & Arras, eds., Ethical Issues in Modern Medicine 8th ed. (New York, McGraw-Hill, 2012) ISBN: 0073535869. Selected articles in PDF format, available on the course Canvas page.
